Q.title: Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 (either Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, or Barron Trump) and (2) there will be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met: (1) one of the following individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024: Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, or Barron Trump; and (2) by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data.

(2) By January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible, with the critical value to look for being 1.8 ˚C.

Then, will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by January 1, 2100? This question will resolve positively if, by that date, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years where the average global temperature each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. The critical value to look for in the NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C.

P.title: Will the price of water on the NQH20 hit $2,500 (2021 USD) per acre-foot by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the price of water hits $2500, adjusted for inflation to 2021 USD, on the NQH20 by 2050-01-01, 00:00 UTC. This question resolves negatively if the price of water does not hit $2500 by that date, and it resolves ambiguously if the NQH20 or a similar exchange doesn't continuously track California water prices up until 2050

The critical value to look for with NASA's dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100.

Q_given_P.title: Given that the cost of water on the NQH20 reaches $2,500 (2021 USD) per acre-foot by the year 2050, will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: The cost of water reaches $2500, adjusted for inflation to 2021 USD, on the NQH20 by 2050-01-01, 00:00 UTC. This will resolve as 'Yes' if the cost of water reaches $2500 by that date, and it will resolve as 'No' if the cost of water does not reach $2500 by that date. 

Then, will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by January 1, 2100? This question will resolve positively if, by that date, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) The cost of water on the NQH20 will reach $2,500 (2021 USD) per acre-foot by the year 2050? (2) There will be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as 'Yes' if BOTH of the following are true: (1) The cost of water reaches $2500, adjusted for inflation to 2021 USD, on the NQH20 by 2050-01-01, 00:00 UTC, and (2) by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. It will resolve as 'No' if either condition is not met.

Resolution Criteria

para_P.title: Will the Forethought Foundation employ over two full-time equivalent staff members in 2025?

Q.title: Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) The Forethought Foundation will have more than two full-time equivalent employees in 2025, and (b) there will be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
1. For the first part, the question will resolve positively if the Forethought Foundation has more than two full-time equivalent employees in 2025, defined as working 35 hours per week, without including volunteers. The question will resolve negatively if the project has clearly been abandoned, otherwise, reports by the organization together with best estimates by Metaculus moderators will be used.
2. For the second part, this question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. The critical value to look for with the specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Will the Forethought Foundation have more than two full-time equivalent employees in 2025? (b) Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P_or_Q.body:
(a) Resolution Criteria for the Forethought Foundation: For the purposes of this question, a full-time equivalent is defined as working 35 hours per week, without including volunteers. The question will be resolved negatively if the project has clearly been abandoned, otherwise, reports by the organization together with best estimates by Metaculus moderators will be used.
(b) Resolution Criteria for global warming: This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data.

Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met: (1) By January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100. (2) The Forethought Foundation will not have more than two full-time equivalent employees in 2025, defined as working 35 hours per week without including volunteers. This question will resolve positively if the project has clearly been abandoned, otherwise, reports by the organization together with best estimates by Metaculus moderators will be used.

(b) This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. Q.title: Will we detect an exoplanet atmosphere with >5% oxygen atmosphere before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if any exoplanet with >5% O2 atmosphere is found before January 1, 2030

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) the Forethought Foundation will employ over two full-time equivalent staff members by 2025, and (b) we will detect an exoplanet atmosphere with >5% oxygen before 2030?
